image.altText: Small child with glasses and blonde hair holds piece of toast.

props.synopsis: As the cost-of-living crisis continues to bite, more schools are offering free breakfast and lunch programs to students — and not-for-profit KickStart for Kids says demand for its meals has surged in the past 12 months.

title.children: School food program in such demand it's going through about 1,000 loaves a week

image.altText: Two police officers stand in front of crime scene tape in a dark street

props.synopsis: Police and paramedics were called to a home in Adelaide's Western suburbs following reports of an unresponsive child. The girl was treated at the scene before being taken to hospital where she has died.

title.children: Major crime investigating after 5yo girl dies in Adelaide

image.altText: Photo of Shane Van Gisbergen's RedBull racecar

props.synopsis: Part of Adelaide's parklands will be turned into a dirt speedway for the 25th year of the Supercars 500 event. While some have criticised the plans, the organiser says the parklands will be left in a "better state than what we found them."

title.children: Temporary dirt speedway set for parklands as Adelaide 500 organisers unveil plans for anniversary event

image.altText: A box full of packets of illegal cigarettes.

props.synopsis: The black market for cigarettes has exploded in plain sight, costing Australia billions in revenue. Some experts say the high price of cigarettes is to blame.

title.children: A black market 'exploded' when cigarettes hit $50 a packet, says one expert. Is cutting the price the answer?

image.altText: Mary-Anne Kenworthy

props.synopsis: Sex workers can now fight "debanking" in some parts of Australia, but others are left hiding their jobs and battling financial discrimination.

title.children: Mary-Anne might be Australia's most famous madam, but her brothel can't take certain credit card payments

image.altText: Sam Millard and Samantha Lilley in a graphic is censored comments from Facebook

props.synopsis: Short statured Australians say photos taken of them without consent are being increasingly distributed and mocked online. They're sick of it and want the wider public to help call it out.

title.children: 'It's become a bit of a sport': The 'disgusting' online abuse faced by Sam and her community

image.altText: A mock up of the live nation and ticketmaster logos on a phone

props.synopsis: The personal details of thousands of Australian customers may have been leaked in the alleged data breach.

title.children: Australians among 560 million users around the world caught in Ticketmaster hack

image.altText: A blackened field following a fire caused by a deadly light plane crash, with police walking and positioning traffic cones.

props.synopsis: A report finds it is likely the pilot of a Cessna plane "lost awareness" of a powerline stretching across his property before clipping it and crashing, killing him and his son.

title.children: Calls for powerline marking programs after light plane crash investigation

image.altText: A black tunnel emerges from a white airliner on an airport tarmac, with people in yellow hi-vis vests standing at the entrance.

props.synopsis: A 73-year-old man died of a suspected heart attack and dozens were injured after flight SQ321, flying from London to Singapore, encountered sudden, extreme turbulence while flying over Myanmar last week.

title.children: Singapore Airlines turbulence investigation finds sharp drop in altitude caused passenger injuries

image.altText: A young woman wearing jeans and a white T-shirt leading a horse wearing a rug

props.synopsis: While Jake Stock was driving on the Dukes Highway in South Australia's south-east, he collided with a car driven by Poppy Crozier — "a vibrant young woman with her whole adult life ahead of her" — who was killed on impact with a truck.

title.children: Driver who pushed teenager's car into path of oncoming truck jailed over deadly 'gross misjudgement'

image.altText: Meat in a butcher's window with Chinese labels

props.synopsis: Five major Australian beef exporters suspended from exporting meat to China can now resume, Agriculture Minister Murray Watt has confirmed.

title.children: Australian beef exports to China can resume after trade war suspension, minister says

image.altText: A jogger runs past a mural with orange, red and purple colours and a wattle flower on a seawall

props.synopsis: The public response to a piece of street art in beachside Adelaide is under fire from the local mayor, who says both the artist and a resident opposed to the mural have been subjected to "online vitriol".

title.children: 'Nasty' and 'disturbing' response to mural along Adelaide beach condemned by mayor

image.altText: The back of a police officer looking towards damaged and overturned carriages

props.synopsis: Rail authorities were alerted to the fatal consequences of a train and truck crash in SA's north when a member of the public answered one of the dead drivers' phones, a preliminary report by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau finds.

title.children: Member of the public picked up dead train driver's phone after horrific truck crash, ATSB reveals

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Jacinda Ardern shake hands.

props.synopsis: Andrew Giles is facing immense pressure over the decision known as Direction 99, but he shows no signs of going anywhere. This mess can be traced back to a meeting of two prime ministers looking to repair a broken relationship.

title.children: The latest immigration mess engulfing Andrew Giles harks back to a fateful meeting between two friendly prime ministers

image.altText: The inside of a warehouse with rows and stacks of soft plastic bundles.

props.synopsis: The deadline for Coles and Woolworths to deal with thousands of tonnes of soft plastic waste left in the collapse of REDcycle has again been extended, in hopes it can be spared from landfill.

title.children: Coles and Woolworths given more time to deal with thousands of tonnes of stranded REDcycle plastic waste

image.altText: Item found during Samantha Murphy search

props.synopsis: Divers were employed to search a dam on a property south of Ballarat on Wednesday, as detectives recovered a phone during a fresh search for evidence.

title.children: Victoria Police to forensically test new 'items of interest' found in search for Samantha Murphy

image.altText: Three children in a car in their child restraints with faces blurred, dark outside

props.synopsis: Jade didn't want her children to witness the abuse she was suffering at the hands of her partner. But after he was charged and denied bail, she struggled to find shelter for her and her three young children.

title.children: Jade's partner is in jail after allegedly abusing her. It's left her and her three children homeless

image.altText: An aerial photo of a desert patch with mining equipment

props.synopsis: The federal government is planning to pour billions of dollars into critical minerals in an effort to build up local production of batteries, solar panels and wind turbines.

title.children: Rare metal vanadium is a key part of the Future Made in Australia policy — if the Senate can be convinced to back it

image.altText: A young woman and man stand next to a vandalised car

props.synopsis: An insurance policy clause means some victims of a vandalism spree won't receive a cent, but others will be fully covered.

title.children: Suburb hit by vandalism spree, but some victims won't receive a cent from insurers

image.altText: Woman holding bottle of drink on light blue background, closeup

props.synopsis: Is your water bottle etched with words of encouragement, urging you to "keep chugging" because you're "almost there"? What happens if you don't drink up?

title.children: Your water bottle might be lying to you. Here's how much you really need to drink

image.altText: Ubirr lookout

props.synopsis: A decade ago Jeffrey Lee gave his uranium-rich land to Kakadu National Park. Now he plans to open it to visitors and tour companies frustrated by ongoing closures of other areas can't wait.

title.children: Amid Kakadu closures, one man plans to open an area unseen to the public

image.altText: A composite image of Keir Starmer and Rishi Sunak

props.synopsis: Jabs about ageism during an election have now made their way across the pond, with the Conservatives taking a page out of Donald Trump's playbook just one week into the campaign.

title.children: Why Britain's Tories are using Trump tactics — and why one expert says they won't translate

image.altText: Bright orange lava erupts from the black ground as smoke pours into the sky

props.synopsis: People have been evacuated from a nearby town and popular tourist destination, as Iceland grapples with the latest eruption.

title.children: Icelandic volcano erupts for fifth time after 400 earthquakes hit the area in a week

image.altText: Two  women walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia headquarters, with the building's name prominent in the background.

props.synopsis: Inflation is rising again, and that's a problem for both the government and the Reserve Bank, writes David Taylor.

title.children: RBA should now 'in theory' hike interest rates in June, but will it?

image.altText: A composite of a man wearing glasses and a yellow scarf next to an AI generated image of the same man.

props.synopsis: Muthuvel Karunanidhi, an iconic Indian actor-turned-politician, made a surprising appearance in January ahead of the Indian election despite being dead for six years. It’s a sign of how deepfakes have influenced this year’s campaign.

title.children: Are deepfakes the frightening future of election campaigns? India is already there

image.altText: An out-of-focus photo of school children walking across a bridge from street view.

props.synopsis: Data obtained by the ABC shows 81,918 suspensions and exclusions were issued in Queensland's public schools in 2023, up by nearly 3,900 on the year before.

title.children: Jess's son has been suspended more than 10 times but still doesn't understand why he can't be at school

image.altText: Bottles labelled hand sanitizer sit on a table with other labels in front of them.

props.synopsis: The AFP are warning importers of the date rape drug known as 'bute' will face heavy penalties after more than 4,000 litres of the substance have been seized in Sydney since a change in legislation in March made it a border-controlled drug.

title.children: Thousands of litres of date rape drug 'bute' found concealed in body oil bottles in Sydney

image.altText: BHP chief executive Andrew Mackenzie silhouetted with logo in the background

props.synopsis: Anglo American has rejected BHP Group's last-ditch request for more time to discuss a $74 billion takeover offer, dismissing it as highly complex and likely ending a five-week pursuit by the bigger rival.

title.children: Anglo American rejects BHP's last-ditch attempt to continue takeover talks

image.altText: Scottie Scheffler holds his golf club while standing in the rain on the practise range.

props.synopsis: World number one golfer Scottie Scheffler says he has "no ill will" towards the officer who arrested him and will not be filing a civil suit after charges against him are dropped.

title.children: Scottie Scheffler keen to move on after all charges against him dropped over arrest outside PGA Championship

image.altText: Mpox viewed under the microscope.

props.synopsis: Experts are advising those at risk to get vaccinated as the state records eight cases of mpox.

title.children: Queensland records eight cases of mpox in one month, formerly known as 'monkeypox'

image.altText: Naomi Osaka slumps her shoulders and throws her head back as she laments in a French Open match against Iga Świątek.

props.synopsis: Three-time French Open winner Iga Świątek calls on fans to show players more respect after they were shouting out during rallies in her second-round blockbuster against Naomi Osaka.

title.children: Naomi Osaka misses match point, drops five straight games to lose to world number one at French Open

image.altText: A man holds a banner that says 'reject the Broadcasting Bill'

props.synopsis: Critics says proposed changes to Indonesia's Broadcasting Law seek to restrict investigative journalism and ensnare journalists, content creators and the public.

title.children: 'I'd rather commit a crime': Indonesian journalists wary of law changes to restrict investigative broadcasts

image.altText: A composite image of bare rocks and eaten grass, alongside tussocks of green grass.

props.synopsis: It's been 10 years since Macquarie Island was declared pest free. Scientists say the transformation of the World Heritage-listed area has been extraordinary, but new threats are on the horizon.

title.children: 'Absolutely extraordinary': 10 years after 'ambitious' eradication program, Macquarie Island remains pest free

image.altText: Laura Tingle at a podium at the National Press Club.

props.synopsis: ABC News director Justin Stevens says comments made by political journalist Laura Tingle at Sydney Writers' Festival did not meet the organisation's editorial standards.

title.children: ABC says Laura Tingle's Sydney Writers' Festival comments did not meet editorial standards

image.altText: Eight items of clothing are hung on black clothes hangers, including three singlets, three pairs of pants, and a white shirt.

props.synopsis: Whether you shop in-store or online, retailers are ramping up sales to entice us to part with our cash. But, as spending flatlines, discounting doesn't appear to have the same effect it used to, sparking warnings of looming retail collapses.

title.children: If you've noticed almost every retail store is having a sale right now, it's because they are. Here's why
